verses.verse: Oracles concerning Babylon, Edom, and Arabia (Isa 13.1; Jer 51.42; Zech 9.14) The oracle concerning the wilderness of the sea. As whirlwinds in the Negeb sweep on, it comes from the desert, from a terrible land.
(Isa 13.17; 33.1; Jer 49.34) A stern vision is told to me; the betrayer betrays, and the destroyer destroys. Go up, O Elam; lay siege, O Media; all the sighing she has caused I bring to an end.
(Isa 13.8; 15.5; 16.11) Therefore my loins are filled with anguish; pangs have seized me like the pangs of a woman in labor; I am bowed down so that I cannot hear; I am dismayed so that I cannot see.
(Deut 28.67) My mind reels; horror has appalled me; the twilight I longed for has been turned for me into trembling.
(Jer 51.39, 57; Dan 5.1-4) They prepare the table; they spread the rugs; they eat; they drink. Rise up, commanders; oil the shield!
For thus the Lord said to me: “Go, post a lookout; let him announce what he sees.
(v 9) When he sees riders, horsemen in pairs, riders on donkeys, riders on camels, let him watch closely, very closely.”
(Hab 2.1) Then the watcher (Q ms Syr Vg: MT a lion) called out: “Upon a watchtower I stand, O Lord, continually by day, and at my post I am stationed throughout the night.

(Isa 46.1; Jer 50.2; 51.8, 44; Rev 14.8; 18.2) Look, there they come, riders, horsemen in pairs!” Then he responded, “Fallen, fallen is Babylon, and all the images of her gods lie shattered on the ground.”
(Jer 51.33) O my threshed and winnowed one, what I have heard from the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, I announce to you.
(Gen 25.14; 32.3) The oracle concerning Dumah. One is calling to me from Seir, “Sentinel, what of the night? Sentinel, what of the night?”
The sentinel says: “Morning comes and also the night. If you will inquire, inquire; come back again.”
(1 Chr 1.9, 32; Isa 13.1; Jer 49.28) The oracle concerning the desert plain. In the scrub of the desert plain you will lodge, O caravans of Dedanites.
(Gen 25.15; Job 6.19) Bring water to the thirsty, O inhabitants of the land of Tema; meet the fugitive with bread.
(Isa 13.14, 15; 17.13) For they have fled from the swords, from the drawn sword, from the bent bow, and from the stress of battle.
(Ps 120.5; Isa 16.14; 17.4; 60.7) For thus the Lord said to me: “Within a year, according to the years of a hired worker, all the glory of Kedar will come to an end,
(Num 23.19; Isa 10.19; Zech 1.6) and the remaining bows of Kedar’s warriors will be few, for the LORD, the God of Israel, has spoken.”
